Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences 27 South Taoyuan Road Taiyuan 030001 China The poor textural properties of initial biochar materials have hindered their extensively applied as catalyst supports. Herein, cellulose biochar materials with the gradient porous and high specific surface area were synthesized by adding different ratios of ZnCl2, and as supports to prepare Pd/Ccel catalysts for efficient maleic acid hydrogenation in water. The characterization results indicated that the textural propertiesand dispersion of Pd in Pd/Ccel catalysts depended on the ratio of ZnCl2 to cellulose. The Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalyst exhibited the best catalytic activity among all catalysts and outstanding stability for reusing 8 times under mild conditions (60 °C, 2 MPa). In addition, this synthesis strategy was also suitable for other biomass materials (glucose, sucrose, and starch) and the catalytic performance of ZnCl2-modified Pd/C catalysts in maleic acid hydrogenation reaction also improved dramatically. The carbonization mechanism was discussed by TG-MS and the results illustrated that ZnCl2 reduced the carbonization temperature and altered the pyrolysis behavior of biochar as a result of excellent catalytic behavior. This work provided a facile and universal strategy for synthesizing biochar high-efficient supported catalysts with gradient porous structure and high specific surface area. Graphical abstract Gradient porous biochar materials with high specific surface area were synthesized by a simple activation process of ZnCl2 and were used as supports to prepare Pd/C catalysts for efficient maleic acid hydrogenation in water. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Gradient porous structure Biochar materials Pd/C catalysts Maleic acid hydrogenation Succinic acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Diminishing petroleum reserves and environmental problems are driving researchers to seek sustainable, green, and environmentally benign resources [1–3]. In this regard, succinic acid (SAc) has attracted attention owing to its multiple applications in the manufacture of dyes, photographic chemicals, surfactants, biodegradable plastics and so on [4–8]. In particular, a global consensus has been reached that biodegradable plastics should be developed for a sustainable future [9,10]. SAc as the important precursor of biodegradable plastics poly (polybutylene succinate) has an addressable market share of billions of dollars. Therefore, improving the production capacity of SAc is quite essential currently. One of the most important ways to obtain SAc is through maleic acid (MAc) or maleic anhydride hydrogenation on supported catalysts by the heterogeneous catalytic process [11–16]. In this progress, due to the strong acidity of MAc aqueous, researchers used to choose some inert or weak redox ability supports, such as activated carbon, titanium dioxide, aluminum oxide, and zirconia, and several types of noble metal-based supported catalysts (such as Pd, Pt, and Ru) since the superior hydrogenation activity [12–14,16]. Researchers have used Pd/C as catalysts to investigate the product distribution of maleic acid hydrogenation reaction under different reaction conditions [17], the reaction mechanism of maleic acid hydrogenation in the aqueous phase [18], and the robustness limits of Pd/C catalysts and their deactivation and regeneration mechanism [19]. However, it is still necessary to improve the performance of the catalysts. Designing the textural properties of the support is an effective method to achieve the purpose. The noble metal intrinsic activity was generally determined by the textural properties of support, especially the porous structure, which directly affects the dispersion of metal and the accessibility of reactants to active sites [20–22]. Unfortunately, commercial activated carbon, mainly micropores, has a small average pore size, resulting in diffusion in the rate-limiting step [23]. Although the mesoporous titanium dioxide, aluminum oxide, and zirconia materials facilitate molecular diffusion, their inherent low specific surface areas also limit the dispersion of noble metals, which is detrimental to catalytic activity and atom economics [24]. Therefore, improving the dispersion of noble metals while reducing the diffusion effect remains a thought-provoking problem to MAc hydrogenation in water. Gradient porous materials can ameliorate this situation because the pore with different sizes has corresponding functions [25,26]. For example, the micro-mesoporous materials, and their micropores structure can provide a large specific surface area for high dispersion of noble metal, while mesopores can facilitate the mass transfer of molecules [27–32]. Such gradient porous structure is beneficial to the mass transfer and contact efficiency in heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Yan et al. [33,34] fabricated a gradient porous Co-Cu-Mn mixed oxides modified ZSM-5 membrane catalyst, which overcame the problems of low contact efficiency of granular ZSM-5 catalyst during isopropanol oxidation. Hung and coworkers [35] designed zeolite@mesoporous silica core-shell nanospheres (ZeoA@MesoS) with a gradient porous structure through a micellar dynamic assembly strategy, which enabled the capillary-directed fast mass transfer from the solutions to inner active sites. Nevertheless, the complex synthesis process and high cost made gradient porous materials still difficult to fabricate in scale. In this context, biochar materials derived from biomass stand out due not only to their low-cost production and sustainable biomass exploitation but also their resistance to acid/basic media and easily tunable porous structure [36–41]. These biochars without any treatment possess poor textural and physicochemical properties. Fortunately, researchers have developed the physical (CO2) and chemical activation (H2SO4, H3PO4, KOH, ZnCl2, etc.) approaches to improve the textural properties [42–45]. Especially chemical activation, it has some intrinsic advantages for the preparation of porous carbon: activator can alter the carbonization process through the role of swelling, dehydration, condensation, etc. to form the porous biochars [27,36]. In these activators, ZnCl2 is an excellent activator candidate, because its mild characteristics facilitate the directional and controllable adjustment of the textural parameters of biochars [42]. José Luis Santos et al. [46,47] have synthesized micro-mesoporous biochar materials through ZnCl2 activated vine shoot and crystalline cellulose. Despite much progress have been achieved in modifying porous biochars, it is still under processive exploration on application of gradient porous biochars as supports in heterogeneous catalytic process. In this work, we used ZnCl2 as an activating agent to regulate the pore structure of biochars and developed a facile method for preparing micro-mesoporous gradient pore supported Pd/C catalyst, which was used for MAc hydrogenation in water. A series of biomass carbon sources (glucose, sucrose, and starch) were successively carbonized in the absence and presence of ZnCl2 to demonstrate the universality of this preparation method. Various characterizations were used to elucidate the effect of ZnCl2 on the textural properties of Pd/C catalysts. Furthermore, the possible carbonization mechanism of biomass was proposed in the presence of ZnCl2 by TG-MS analysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material Glucose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, maleic acid (≥99.0%, AR), glutaconic acid, itaconic acid (≥99.0%, AR), and PdCl2 were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. ZnCl2, trans-3-hexenedioic acid (≥98.0%, AR) NaOH and ethanol were purchased from Macklin. HCl, NaBH4, ZrO2, TiO2 (P25), and α-Al2O3 were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. H2 and N2 were provided by Shanxi Yihong Gas Industry Co., Ltd. Commercial activated carbon (AC) was purchased from Shanxi Xinhua Activated Carbon Co., Ltd. Distilled water was used in all experiments. All the reagents were analytic purity grade and were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation and characterizations The carbonization experiments were performed in a tube furnace. For the typical procedure: firstly, the cellulose with different ratios of ZnCl2 (1:0, 1:0.5, 1:1.5, 1:3, and 1:5 mass ratio) were heated to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere (50 mL/min) for 1 h at 3.3 °C/min. Then, the carbonized product was washed three times at 60 °C in 3 mol/L HCl solution. Finally, the black powder was dried overnight at 120 °C. The obtained Ccel supports were denoted as CcelZnCl2(1:0), CcelZnCl2(1:0.5), CcelZnCl2(1:1.5), CcelZnCl2(1:3) and CcelZnCl2(1:5). Besides, the precursors (glucose, sucrose, and starch) without ZnCl2 and with ZnCl2 (1:3 mass ratio) were treated according to the above recipe. The obtained supports were denoted as CgluZnCl2(1:0), CgluZnCl2(1:3), CsucZnCl2(1:0), CsucZnCl2(1:3), CstaZnCl2(1:0) and CstaZnCl2(1:3). Palladium (1 wt.%, nominal value) was supported on the prepared biochars by wetness impregnation using the HCl solution of PdCl2. Once the impregnation was completed, NaOH solution was added to adjust pH to 9–12. Then, 10 mL NaBH4 solution (1 mol/L) was added to the flask containing the impregnated Pd catalyst, the content of which was filtered after stirring for 3 h and the residue was washed with a large amount of distilled water and ethanol, dried at 120 °C in a vacuum oven for 12 h. The obtained catalysts were denoted as Pd/C( x )ZnCl2( y ) (x represents different precursors, and y represents the ratio of precursor to ZnCl2). TiO2, α-Al2O3, ZrO2 and commercial activated carbon (AC) as supports were impregnated by the HCl solution of PdCl2, and the same procedure was used to prepare the 1% Pd/TiO2, Pd/α-Al2O3, Pd/ZrO2 and Pd/AC catalysts. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ=1.54187 Å, 40 kV and 40 mA) in a 2θ angle from 10° to 90° The stacking height parameters (Lc) were calculated by the empirical Braggs and Scherrer equations [48]: (1) L c = K c λ β 002 c o s θ 002 where Kc is a constant determined by the diffracted plane (0.89 for the (002)). λ refers to the used X-ray wavelength (1.54 Å for Cu Kα radiation). β 002 is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of selected peak. θ 002 refers to the Bragg angle of the (002) plane. The empirical R-value is defined as the ratio of the (002) peak intensity relative to the background at the same scattering angle [49]. Lower R-values indicate higher single layers concentrations, with R=1 indicating no (002) peak in the XRD pattern. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of samples was carried out in a JEM-2100F TEM equipped with an attachment for local energy dispersion analysis (EDX) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV in both high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and scanning transmission (STEM) mode. STEM images were obtained using a high-angle annular dark-filed detector (HAADF) which allows Z-contrast imaging. The average particle size of Pd was determined over 100 single particles measurements using the surface distribution according to the following equation: (2) D p = ∑ n i d i 3 ∑ n i d i 2 where di is the geometric diameter of the i th particle, and ni is the number of particles. The metal dispersion was estimated from the average particle size obtained from TEM analysis, the real metal content measured from ICP (ICP-AES, Thermo iCAP6300). These synthesized materials were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL JSM-7900F) using an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of samples were performed on a Tristar II (3020) gas adsorption analyzer. The specific surface areas were investigated by the multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution was measured by Original Density Functional Theory. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Kratos AXIS ULTRA DLD spectrometer with Al Kα radiation and multichannel detector. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) spectra were achieved with a Setaram Evolution 16/18 thermogravimetric analyzer coupled to a mass spectrometer (OMNIstar/quadrupole mass analyzer; Pfeiffer Vacuum). 2.3 Catalytic tests All reactions were carried out in a titanium autoclave equipped with a pressure gauge, automatic temperature control apparatus, and magnetic stirring. In a typical experiment, the autoclave was charged with MAc (15 mmol), water (30 mL), catalyst (0.05 g), and H2 (2 MPa). The reaction mixture was kept at 60 °C and vigorous stirring (800 rpm). After reaction for 2 h, the products, and by-products were identified and quantified by HPLC. MAc conversions, SAc selectively, and yield were calculated according to the following formulas: (3) MAc conversion ( mol % ) = m MAc 0 − m MAc m MAc 0 × 100 % (4) SAc selectivity ( mol % ) = m SAc m MAc 0 − m MAc × 100 % (5) SAc yield ( mol % ) = m SAc m MAc 0 × 100 % where m 0 MAc denotes the initial moles of MAc, m MAc refers to the residual moles of MAc after 2 h, and m SAc signifies the moles of produced SAc. In the kinetic experiments, two titanium tubes were equipped with the autoclave for in situ sampling during the reaction. The amount of solvent was expanded to 40 mL, and the reaction time was shortened to 80 min to control the conversion rate. Other reaction conditions were the same as the typical experiments. 0.5 mL of the reaction mixture was taken out for each measurement. Reaction rate constant and activation energy were calculated according to the Eqs. (6) and (7) [16]: (6) ln C 0 C = k t (7) k = A e − E a R T where C 0 is initial moles of MAc, C refers to the moles of MAc at time t, k is the rate constant at temperature T, Ea is the apparent activation energy of reaction (KJ/mol), and R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J K −1 mol−1). The hydrogenation reaction of trans-3-hexenedioic acid, glutaconic acid, and itaconic acid was performed in the conditions of typical experiments. And the reactants and products were analyzed by 1H NMR [50–52]. 1H NMR experiments were conducted on a Bruker AV-Ⅲ 400 MHz NMR spectrometer (9.93 T) with a 5 mm PABBO BB/19F-1H/D probe equipped with z-gradient coil and a maximum nominal gradient strength of 50 G∙cm−1. For reusability tests, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture after each reaction run. Then it was washed thoroughly with distilled water and ethanol (10 mL × 5 times) and finally dried at 80 °C for 12 h in an oven before the next run. The reaction conditions in all the recycling runs were the same as the typical experiments. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of Pd/Ccel catalysts Cellulose biochars were activated by using different ratios of ZnCl2 and as precursors to prepare Pd/Ccel catalysts. Fig. 1 provided the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of all samples. The Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0), Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0.5), and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:1.5) exhibited type I isotherms typical of microporous materials in Fig. 1a, while the isotherm curves of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5) were typical type IV, characteristic of mesoporous materials. The lack of equilibrium of adsorption isotherms for Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0.5) (Figure S1) were due to the narrow microporosity [53]. Apparently, pore diameters were also always bigger for these samples treated by ZnCl2 in Fig. 1b. In addition, the nitrogen uptake at a low relative pressure (P/P0<0.3) reflects the evolution of specific surface area [47]. The sharp increase of nitrogen uptake of Pd/Ccel after being treated by ZnCl2 implied that ZnCl2 could exert a large specific surface. The textural parameters of all samples calculated from the isotherms data were summarized in Table 1 . With the increase of ZnCl2 ratio, the specific surface area of Pd/Ccel catalysts also gradually increased and reached the highest value (2111.3 m2/g) with maximum volume (1.245 cm3/g) for Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3). However, compared with the Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3), the specific surface area and pore volume of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5) decreased to 1832.4 m2/g and 1.242 cm3/g, respectively. The increase in pore volume may be explained by a possible partial gasification induced by ZnCl2 to lead to a partial liberation of pores filled with amorphous carbon [54]. This result indicated that only a moderate amount of ZnCl2 would extend the maximum total surface area, which accorded with the results of Wróbel-Iwaniec and Liu [45,46]. Besides, the mesoporosity of Pd/Ccel catalysts also increased significantly from 0.9% of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) to 64.2% of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5) and finally forming the micro-mesoporous gradient porous biochar materials. A large specific surface area of support is beneficial to the high dispersion of metals, and the improvement of mesoporosity of support would facilitate reactants diffusion to the metal active centers [27], which could make in consequence these materials promising catalysts. The surface structure of Pd/Ccel catalysts was analyzed by XPS. Fig. 2 a showed the evolution of XPS signal intensity of O species in Pd/Ccel and the total O/C content also were summarized in Table 2 . Obviously, the total O/C content presented a continued decrease with the increase of ZnCl2 ratio. Additionally, some proportion of the oxygen groups with higher O 1 s electron binding energies shifted to the lower O 1 s electron binding energies in Fig. 2b, which meant the present form of O species had changed. Therefore, the deconvoluted O 1 s XPS core levels were shown in Fig. 2c. The deconvoluted peaks located at the binding energies of ∼531.5, 532.5, 534.5, 535.5, and 536.5 eV were attributed to the quinone, C(O)O, -OH, CO-C and adsorbed water, respectively [55–57]. The quantitative results in Table 2 showed that the oxygen content in the form of carbonyl (quinone) and carboxylic acid groups increased with the increase of ZnCl2 ratio, whereas the content in the form of hydroxyl groups and epoxy was not linear with the ZnCl2 ratio. Previous studies have already reported carbonyl and carboxyl oxygen on the surface of biochar are beneficial to prepare high dispersion and stability metal-supported catalysts by metal-support interaction [58]. Overall, the activation by ZnCl2 would affect the distribution of surface functional groups of Pd/Ccel, which may be due to the difference in gasification liberation amount induced by ZnCl2, and this phenomenon was further explained by the latter TG-MS results. The detailed structural parameters of Pd/Ccel catalysts were analyzed by XRD (Fig. 3 ) and the main physicochemical and structural features were summarized in Table 3 . All catalysts contained distinguishable crystalline characters corresponding to (002) and (100) diffraction peaks (at 2θ = 24.7° and 43.1°, respectively), which are indicative of the graphitization degree and crystallinity of samples [48]. A small shift in the Bragg diffraction angle of (002) lines was visible in Fig. 3. Thus, in order to further evaluate the graphitization degree of samples, the lattice parameters were quantitatively analyzed by L c and R value, which reflected the stacking height parameter and the single layers concentration of carbon materials, respectively [49]. As can be seen in Table 3, all samples exhibited high crystallite height (L c) values, indicating low values of stacking height between the graphene sheets. In addition, the R values of all samples were >1, which indicated a low concentration of single carbon layers, meaning high graphitization. Evidently, R factors and L c parameters of all samples were comparable, and neither carbon structure organization was influenced by the different treatments of ZnCl2 ratio. When palladium particle was taken into consideration, the differences in diffraction intensity and width of these samples were significant. Several diffraction peaks corresponding to palladium metal phase (2θ = 40.1°, 46.7°, 68.1°, 82.1° and 86.6° due to (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) family planes, respectively) of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) were detected in Fig. 3. Nevertheless, no palladium metal phase diffraction peaks were observed for Pd/Ccel catalysts once their supports were treated by ZnCl2. More directly, the quantitative results from XRD in Table 3 showed the mean particle size of Pd in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) was 38.7 nm while the value significantly decreased below the detection limit of XRD for the Pd/Ccel catalysts which their supports were treated by ZnCl2. The evolution of the mean particle size of Pd in Pd/Ccel catalysts can be directly observed by TEM. Therefore, the TEM experiments (Fig. 4 ) were performed on all samples, and the quantitative data were presented in Table 3. The interplanar crystal spacing of the particle was 0.23 nm (Fig. 4b), corresponding to (111) facet of Pd° crystal. The mean particle size of Pd in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) was 47.9 nm. With the increase of ZnCl2 ratio, the mean particle size of Pd rapidly decreased to 9.3, 4.9, and 2.0 nm for the Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0.5), Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:1.5) and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3), respectively. On the contrary, the value was increased slightly to 5.1 nm for Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5) catalyst. Correspondingly, the dispersion of Pd in Pd/Ccel also presented the same variation trend as the mean particle size of Pd. Notably, a clear relationship between the mean particle size of Pd and the specific surface area of Pd/Ccel can be observed. Contrasting the dispersions and textural properties, it is possible to deduce that higher specific surface areas and pore volumes facilitate metal dispersion, namely higher the specific surface areas, the higher the metal dispersion and, therefore, the lower the mean particle size of Pd. The porosity is also related to metal dispersion, such as the higher microporosity (99.1% in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0)) leading to larger particle size (47.9 nm). Indeed, the micro-mesoporous structure is also of primordial importance to stabilize metal high dispersion. STEM technique allows greater contrast than TEM, thus a STEM study was also performed over two representative samples, Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) to evaluate catalysts’ dispersion (Fig. 5 ). Both HAADF micrographs (Fig. 5a and b) and STEM mapping (Fig. 5c and d) confirmed the higher dispersion of Pd in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) than Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0). In a word, the mean particle size and dispersion of Pd in Pd/Ccel catalysts can be customized by tailoring the textural and surface properties with ZnCl2. The microstructures of Pd/Ccel catalysts were studied by SEM. SEM images of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) catalyst showed the organized and regular rod structure with twists and folds in Fig. 6 . With the increase of ZnCl2 ratio, the rod-like structure was gradually broken, showing the structure of rod-like and block-like staggered in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0.5), full bulk in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:1.5), and lamellar structure in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5). These results indicated the morphology of catalysts was also significantly influenced by ZnCl2. 3.2 Catalytic activity The catalytic performances of Pd/Ccel catalysts in MAc hydrogenation to SAc in water were presented in Fig. 7 a. The conversion of MAc and the selectivity of SAc obtained from Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0.5), Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:1.5), and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) exhibited the same increasing tendency compared with that from Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0). These results indicated that the activation treatment of ZnCl2 significantly improved the catalytic activity of Pd/Ccel catalysts. However, when the ratio of cellulose to ZnCl2 was increased from 1:3 to 1:5, the conversion of MAc was a slight drop from 100 mol% to 95.2 mol% (Table S1). Obviously, the variety of catalytic activity of Pd/Ccel catalysts is quite consistent with the textural properties, especially the specific surface area and dispersion of Pd. ZnCl2 tailors the textural parameters of biochars (specific surface area, porous structure, and surface functional groups), thereby optimizing the particle size and dispersion of Pd, and ultimately improving the catalytic performance of Pd/C catalysts. In addition, it was worth noting that the selectivity of SAc always remained 100 mol% once cellulose was pretreated by ZnCl2, which suggested that the rapid hydrogenation of MAc prevented the accumulation of isomerized product fumaric acid. This result manifested that Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) activated with moderate ZnCl2 would show the best catalytic performance. In order to get insight into the intrinsic activity of Pd/Ccel catalysts in MAc hydrogenation, the kinetic experiments were carried out. The plot of ln(C0 /C) versus time of each catalyst was measured (Fig. S2) and the linear relationship indicated that the reaction of MAc hydrogenation to SAc exhibited a first-order reaction in all catalysts [16]. Then, the apparent activation energy (Ea ) in all catalysts was calculated based on the Arrhenius plot in Fig. 7b. As shown in Fig. 7c, the apparent activation energy over Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0), Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0.5), Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:1.5), Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) and Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5) were 71.92, 65.54, 56.00, 40.46 and 41.84 KJ/mol, respectively. It can be seen the activation energy barrier over Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) was higher than the catalysts pretreated by ZnCl2. The activation of ZnCl2 leads to the high dispersion of Pd, which may expose more active sites for MAc hydrogenation system, resulting in a decrease in apparent activation energy. More notably, the apparent activation energy of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) was close to that of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5), which can be attributed to the balance between the dispersion of Pd and micr-mesoporosity. Among these Pd/Ccel catalysts, the Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) have the highest dispersion of Pd (50%), while holding the highest mesoporosity (64.2%) was the Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5). High microporosity can provide high specific surface area to promote the dispersion of Pd. However, too high microporosity is bound to limit the diffusion of molecules and thus improve the reaction energy barrier. The presence of mesopores can contribute to the diffusion of molecules, thereby eliminating the microporous confinement effect and reducing the reaction energy barrier. Thus, high metal dispersion and suitable micr-mesoporous gradient porous structure are crucial for MAc hydrogenation. Herein, we optimized the textural properties of biochar materials by regulating the ratio of ZnCl2 and gained the gradient porous Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalysts with high specific surface area, which exhibited the best catalytic activity and achieved the efficient MAc hydrogenation in water. The catalyst stability is also an important factor for the sustainable industrialization of MAc hydrogenation. Thus, the reusability of the reduced Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalyst was tested for MAc hydrogenation (Fig. 7d). As a comparison, the recycling stabilities of other Pd-based catalysts which used commercial activated carbon (AC) and common oxide (TiO2, α-Al2O3, and ZrO2) as supported were also tested. The information of Pd/AC were shown in Figures S3-S5. It can be seen that the initial activity of Pd/AC was much lower than that of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) (Fig. 7d). The BET specific surface area was only 246.3 m2/g (Table S4), resulting in the large average particle size (13.4 nm) and the low dispersion (7%) of Pd/AC in (Table S3), which may be the reason for the lower initial activity of Pd/AC. After eight consecutive runs, a noticeable activity loss was observed for Pd/AC whereas the catalyst of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) remained highly active. ICP results (Table S5) showed that Pd particles in Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) could be better stabilized with little falling off than that in Pd/AC. As a consequence, Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) showed better performance than Pd/AC. In addition, the initial activity of Pd-based catalysts when the oxides were used as carrier were comparable to that of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3). When the Pd/TiO2, Pd/α-Al2O3, and Pd/ZrO2 were reused for 8 times, the yield of MAc decreased from 98.04 mol%, 99.02 mol% and 98.07 mol% to 59.35 mol%, 40.87 mol% and 36.17 mol%, respectively (Table S2). The Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalyst still maintained a good SAc yield (>96 mol%) after reusing 8 times. ICP analysis of the spent catalysts of Pd/TiO2, Pd/α-Al2O3, and Pd/ZrO2 showed that there were varying degrees of losses of metal content (Table S5) while the metal content of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) hardly reduced. Metal oxide supports may have poor anti-acid which caused loss of active metals. The above results showed that the reduced Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic stability. And the reason for good stability can be attributed to the excellent anti-acid of biochar supports and interaction between the surface carbonyl oxygen and Pd active phase. Moreover, we tried to investigate the more wide application in selective hydrogenation of other unsaturated carboxylic acids for Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3), including trans-3-hexenedioic acid, glutaconic acid, and itaconic acid. The 1H NMR (Figs. S6–S8) spectra for pure substrates and reaction products were listed in Table 4 . The hydrogenation of three substrates exhibited 100 mol% conversions and 100 mol% selectivities toward target saturated diacids. These results suggested the Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalyst possessed superior selective hydrogenation catalytic activities in unsaturated carboxylic acids C=C hydrogenation reaction. 3.3 The application of ZnCl2-modified biochars Hereinbefore, we have demonstrated that the gradient porous Pd/Ccel catalysts with a high specific surface area can be synthesized by a facile activation process of ZnCl2 and showed excellent catalytic performance in selective hydrogenation reactions of unsaturated carboxylic acids. It is worth studying whether the activation of ZnCl2 is effective for other common biomass sources. Therefore, glucose, sucrose, and starch were chosen as precursors to be carbonized under the condition of without ZnCl2 and the 1:3 ratio of biomass to ZnCl2, and they were as supports to prepare the Pd-base catalysts. The specific surface area, pore volume, and mesoporosity of Pd/CgluZnCl2(1:3), Pd/CsucZnCl2(1:3), and Pd/CstaZnCl2(1:3) sharply increased compared with Pd/CgluZnCl2(1:0), Pd/CsucZnCl2(1:0) and Pd/CstaZnCl2(1:0) (Figure S9, Table S6). Meanwhile, the Lc parameters and R factors (Table S3) from XRD (Fig. 8 a) were also comparable, which indicated the support organization from these biomass materials was not also influenced by the treatment of ZnCl2. In addition, the quantitative results (Table S3) calculated from TEM (Figure S10) showed ZnCl2 significantly reduced the mean particle size of Pd and improved the dispersion of Pd. These results confirmed that ZnCl2 optimized the textural properties of Pd/Cglu, Pd/Csuc, and Pd/Csta catalysts, as the Pd/Ccel catalysts. These catalysts were used in MAc hydrogenation reaction (Fig. 8b). After 2 h reaction, the three corresponding catalysts of Pd/CgluZnCl2(1:0), Pd/CsucZnCl2(1:0), and Pd/CstaZnCl2(1:0) gave SAc yields of 66.6 mol%, 65.6 mol% and 60.2 mol%, respectively (Table S7). For the catalysts of Pd/CgluZnCl2(1:3), Pd/CsucZnCl2(1:3) and Pd/CstaZnCl2(1:3), the yield of SAc were 99.2 mol%, 95.1 mol%, and 100 mol%, respectively. More importantly, these catalysts pretreated by ZnCl2 achieved the maximum yield of 66.6 mol% only within 30 min, compared to 2 h for the catalysts without ZnCl2 treatment. It was obvious that the catalytic activity of biochars-derived catalysts after being pretreated by ZnCl2 was significantly improved. These results supported that the modification for biochar materials by ZnCl2 could be successfully extended to other biochar materials systems. 3.4 Carbonization mechanism ZnCl2 significantly modified the textural properties and surface functional groups of biochars and improved the catalytic performance of Pd/C catalysts. It is necessary to study the activation mechanism of ZnCl2 during the carbonization process of biomass. Therefore, TG-MS was used in the carbonization process of cellulose alone and the cellulose mixture ZnCl2 (1:3) to look insight into the effect of ZnCl2. Fig. 9 compared the thermal stability of the CcelZnCl2(1:0) and CcelZnCl2(1:3) by TG and DTG. A typical one-step weight loss was observed for pure cellulose. The first weight loss at 280 to 400 °C corresponded to the thermal decomposition of cellulose, agreeing well with the previous work. [42]. When adding ZnCl2, a multistep weight loss was shown in TG and DTG of Fig. 9, which meant pyrolysis behaviors were changed significantly. The first weight loss stage (I) at 100 to 280 °C was related to the removal of physisorbed water and the complete carbonization process of cellulose. [43]. This value was lower than that of pure cellulose (∼352 °C), indicating an improved yield of biochar and a decrease of O/C content in Pd/C catalysts surface in XPS spectra. The second stage (II) was 280 to 420 °C in TG and DTG. In this stage, the weight of the sample slowly decline due to the swelling effect and produced pore structures by adding ZnCl2 in the aromatization reaction [42]. A significant mass loss at 420–650 °C in the third stage (III) was related to the evaporation of ZnCl2. The evaporation temperature of ZnCl2 was found at nearly 560 °C, which was in line with obtained TG result of pure ZnCl2 (Fig. S11). The slow carbonization process of the residual carbon was an observation from 650 to 800 °C in the last loss weight (IV).Analyzing the volatiles released during the carbonization process is conducive to carefully studying the surface chemistry of biochars. Thus, water vapor, carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), and light hydrocarbon (primarily CH4 and C2H6) as the main species [42] produced during the carbonization process of cellulose were monitored by online MS (Figure S12). The MS signals for all monitored gases shifted to low temperatures, suggesting ZnCl2 reduced the carbonization temperature of biomass. More importantly, the signal intensity for all monitored gases was also significantly reduced after adding ZnCl2 to cellulose, which indicated the improvement of the carbon yield, as the TG results. In detail, CO2 mainly came from the decomposition of carboxylic groups [43]. The reduction of the total released amount of CO2 after adding ZnCl2 to cellulose led to the increase of carbonyl and carboxylic acid groups on the surface of the carbon support, which was consistent with the XPS results. These results illustrated ZnCl2 positively accelerated the carbonization process and optimized the textural parameters of biochar which resulted in the excellent catalytic performance of Pd/C. 4 Conclusion The textural and surface properties of biochar materials have been optimized by a simple activation process of ZnCl2 and as supports to synthesize the gradient porous Pd/C catalysts with high specific surface area. Based on the characterization results of Pd/Ccel catalysts, the presence of ZnCl2 exerted a large specific surface from 437.6 of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) to 2111.3 m2/g of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3), developed mesoporosity from 0.9 mol% of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:0) to 64.2 mol% of Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:5) and increased the content of surface carbonyl oxygen. These combined effects finally resulted in the lower particle size and higher dispersion of Pd. Among these Pd/Ccel catalysts, the Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) exhibited the best catalytic activity (MAc conversion: 100 mol%, SAc yield: 100 mol%) and anti-acid capability for MAc and other unsaturated carboxylic acids hydrogenation reaction which can be attributed to the maximum specific surface area and appropriate micro-mesoporosity. Moreover, the method of ZnCl2 modifying biochars has been extended to other biomass sources such as glucose, sucrose, and starch. The TG-MS finally confirmed the optimization of textural properties was due to that the presence of ZnCl2 reducing the carbonization temperature and altering the pyrolysis behavior of biomass carbon. The method to prepare gradient porous biochar materials developed in this manuscript provided more potential possibilities for the utilization of biomass resources. coredata.dc:description: The poor textural properties of initial biochar materials have hindered their extensively applied as catalyst supports. Herein, cellulose biochar materials with the gradient porous and high specific surface area were synthesized by adding different ratios of ZnCl2, and as supports to prepare Pd/Ccel catalysts for efficient maleic acid hydrogenation in water. The characterization results indicated that the textural propertiesand dispersion of Pd in Pd/Ccel catalysts depended on the ratio of ZnCl2 to cellulose. The Pd/CcelZnCl2(1:3) catalyst exhibited the best catalytic activity among all catalysts and outstanding stability for reusing 8 times under mild conditions (60 °C, 2 MPa). In addition, this synthesis strategy was also suitable for other biomass materials (glucose, sucrose, and starch) and the catalytic performance of ZnCl2-modified Pd/C catalysts in maleic acid hydrogenation reaction also improved dramatically. The carbonization mechanism was discussed by TG-MS and the results illustrated that ZnCl2 reduced the carbonization temperature and altered the pyrolysis behavior of biochar as a result of excellent catalytic behavior. This work provided a facile and universal strategy for synthesizing biochar high-efficient supported catalysts with gradient porous structure and high specific surface area.
coredata.dc:title: Gradient porous biochar materials with high specific surface area as supports for Pd/C catalysts for efficient maleic acid hydrogenation
